bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to W. Edwin Hemphill, November 2, 1951

div1.p: Hench will send Hemphill a copy of Reed's medical diploma and a photograph of his birthplace. These will be used in an article published by the Virginia State University.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to W. Edwin Hemphill, November 2, 1951
div1.opener:
November 2, 1951
Dr. W. Edwin Hemphill
Head, History Division
Virginia State Library
Richmond 19, Virginia
My dear Doctor Hemphill:
div1.p:
I have asked our Photographic Department to prepare an 8" by 10"
glossy print of Walter Reed's medical diploma from the University
of Virginia; also glossy prints of Walter Reed's birthplace before
and after it was fixed up. The latter two are copies of either
post cards or small photographs that were sent to me by someone and
may be what you already have. If you do not use them, please return
them to me. Our Photographic Department expects to have them finished
by Monday and I will mail them to you then.

In regard to the credit line under the photograph of Reed's diploma,
perhaps it might be best to say “The Reed Family through Dr. P. S.
Hench.” I never quite know what to do about such a matter. On a
number of occasions I have suggested the following credit lines:
“Mrs. Walter Reed” or “Mrs. Walter Reed and Dr. P. S. Hench,” but
Mrs. Reed is now dead, she died last year. The reason I did this in
the past was to relieve her of letters of inquiry or requests re-
garding photographs. General Reed, the son, is as you may know, a
quiet retiring man who simply hates to write letters and unless the
matter is a special one he rarely answers them. The many photographs,
letters and documents which the Reed family gave me they gave me out-
right, but of course with the understanding that they were to be part
of a large collection of which I was to be the custodian, which of
course would be kept together and not sold and I have been the one to
decide which requests for data it was proper for me to grant, etc.
Naturally, I feel a great responsibility in this matter and want to be
as helpful as possible, but of course there are certain things that I
want to keep and not publish until my own book on the subject comes out.
I shall be glad to have your own ideas as to the matter of the credit
line and I notice the credit lines in your magazine are not under the
photographs but on the back of the cover page. That is certainly all
right with me.

Would you send me a copy of your article when it is published? I am sure
that Walter Reed's daughter and son would like to have copies also and if
you will send them to me I will forward them, or perhaps you may wish to
send them directly.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
P.S.: Since dictating the above letter I have discussed the above matter
with Dr. James Eckman, Head of our Editorial Department. He thinks that the
credit line “The Reed Family through Dr. P. S. Hench” would be appropriate.
